data.title: Love Crime (2010)
data.meta_description: In the sterile setting of a powerful multinational, a ruthless corporate executive and her ambitious protégée bare their claws in a vicious battle for supremacy.
data.text:
Love Crime is an absolutely ridiculous psychological thriller that I wasn't quite getting the thread of for the first 20 minutes or so.

There seemed to be the germ of a more interesting relationship between Ludivine Sagnier and Kristin Scott Thomas than the workplace rivalry that turns murderous between them at the beginning. However, it gets lost somewhere in a love triangle that gets entangled in financial murkiness and as such it only really starts to become coherent and an actual watchable film when it decides to go a safer route.

I think part of the reason I wasn't picking up the thread of this at the outset though was because it was littered with occasionally almost comic sex scenes,…

Isabelle is a talented and ambitious young woman who works for a major transnational company under Christine, a powerful woman who always gets what she wants, no matter what resources she has to turn to. When the young woman sees an opportunity to get out of the shadow of her superior, Christine sees her future threatened and will not stop until she destroys Isabelle's career. Crime d'amour is a film divided into two parts, both equally inconsistent and with a tone that is not well defined. The first act establishes the strange dynamics of the protagonists without giving too many explanations, the conflict and the rupture of the relationship, as well as the chaos that it becomes. At some point…
